title-group.article-title: Perinatal mental health services: what are they and why do we need them?

sec.title: Objective:
sec.p: To review the evidence for perinatal mental health as a sub-specialist area of mental health and describe the development of a service model.

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: Perinatal mental health is emerging as a sub-specialist area of mental health with specific knowledge and expertise in assessment, diagnosis and treatment. It requires services to ensure that women and infants receive optimal care across pregnancy and the postpartum.

body.p: Psychiatric illness is one of the leading indirect causes of maternal mortality in Australia.1 Perinatal mental health under its broadest definition covers mental illness from pre-conception planning through pregnancy until three years postpartum. In many ways it shares more with sub-specialties such as child psychiatry or old age psychiatry, given it is focused on a specific developmental period with unique disorders, altered biological and physiological processes and additional treatment risks. The idea of an emerging area of perinatal mental health has been discussed for some time in the context of the effect of mental illness across pregnancy and the postpartum on infant outcomes and the need for a more integrated approach.2,3 However, it is becoming even more clear that perinatal mental health covers a unique knowledge base and hence the requirement for specific sub-specialist skills and service delivery models. In this paper, an outline of this growing sub-specialist area will be examined.

sec.title: Mental illness in pregnancy and postpartum
sec.p: Each of the following disorders described below carries unique risks for both mother and child across the perinatal period. These will be briefly outlined.

sec.title: Bipolar affective disorder
sec.p: Women with bipolar affective disorder (BPAD) have an increased risk of developing symptoms during the perinatal period, with the relapse risk for those who cease medication doubling during pregnancy4 and reaching at least 70% postpartum.5,6 Symptom emergence is usually rapid, occurring in the final weeks of pregnancy or early postpartum, although prophylactic lithium has been found to significantly reduce the rate of relapse.7 Pregnancies in this group are more likely to be complicated by antenatal haemorrhage, low birth weight, intra-uterine growth retardation (IUGR) and preterm labour,8 in addition to the effects of mood stabilising medication on the developing foetus, including potential longer term poorer developmental outcomes.9–11

sec.title: Schizophrenia
sec.p: Risks for women with schizophrenia in the perinatal period include: increased likelihood of unplanned pregnancies, suboptimal antenatal nutrition and care, higher rates of maternal obesity, and increased rates of maternal substance use.12 Psychotic episodes during pregnancy double the rate of adverse pregnancy outcomes.13 Infants born to mothers with schizophrenia are at increased risk of low birth weight and IUGR, preterm delivery and low APGAR scores,14 as well as the consequences of disrupted attachment and bonding, insensitive, intrusive care,15,16 and periods of foster care.17 There is an almost doubling of the risk of foetal death and stillbirth,18 and increased rates of abuse, neglect19 and infanticide.20

Guidelines for the management of women with a history of BPAD and schizophrenia from preconception through to the postpartum period have been developed, emphasising the importance of collaboration between obstetrics and mental health in the delivery of services.21 Early data evaluating this service initiative has been optimistic with respect to a reduction in relapse rates and improved outcomes for mothers and infants compared with previously published data.

sec.title: Borderline personality disorder
sec.p: Borderline personality disorder (BPD) is associated with considerable psychosocial impairment and significant risk of psychiatric and physical co-morbidity such as anxiety and depressive disorders, substance abuse and eating disorders.22 All these disorders carry increased risks for the mother and infant during the perinatal period. There is a high risk for women with BPD to have a history of developmental trauma, including childhood sexual abuse, and pregnancy, childbirth and parenting may reactivate past traumas.23

Women with BPD report feeling far less satisfied with their parenting,24 experience higher levels of parenting stress, and they have been found to parent more intrusively and less sensitively.25 Infants of women with BPD are at increased risk of developing insecure attachment styles26 and young children of women with BPD have increased role reversal, fear of abandonment, negative expectations of maternal and paternal relationships and poorer emotional regulation.27 Children are also at risk of developing attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and conduct disorders and are more likely to be living away from home.28,29
Currently there is only one guideline published for the management of BPD in the perinatal period,30 with no data available on the evaluation of its implementation.

sec.title: Eating disorders
sec.p: Eating disorder symptoms may improve during pregnancy31,32 but postpartum relapse is common33,34 and there are high rates of antenatal and postnatal depression.35 Findings from research into pregnancy and neonatal outcomes for women with eating disorders (EDs) have been mixed. The majority of studies report higher rates of Caesarean section, delivery with infants more likely to be premature and of lower birth weight36,37 with a higher risk of developmental delay38 and congenital malformations.35 Other researchers report that the majority have normal pregnancies and deliver healthy babies33 and find no association with adverse neonatal outcomes.39 Postpartum, abnormal eating behaviours may extend to the infant32 and manifest as failure to thrive or difficulty with breastfeeding.40

sec.title: Antenatal depression and postnatal depression
sec.p: Antenatal and postnatal depression affect at least 14% of Australian women and, untreated, this has the potential for long term health and mental health consequences for both mother and child.41 Even more common is the ‘baby blues’, a self limiting condition with onset within the first week postpartum.

There has been some controversy as to whether antenatal depression (AND) and postnatal depression (PND) are psychiatric disorders in their own right or whether they simply represent major depression that coincidentally arises during this part of the lifecycle. Riecher-Rossler and Hoflecker concluded that there was no evidence for a ‘specific aetiology nor for a clearly distinct psychopathology’ but still suggested the use of the term was justified due to the ‘specific needs for care’ that PND requires and in particular the effects on offspring.42

A number of risk factors have been identified for PND. Moderate risk factors were found to be depression/ anxiety during pregnancy, stressful life event during pregnancy or early puerperium, low level of social support and past history of depression.43,44 An Australian study found that previous psychopathology, antenatal depression/anxiety, being adolescent, being socially disadvantaged, having a poor marital relationship, poor social supports, and adverse early life experiences were associated with a risk of PND.45 Hormonal factors have been investigated for their role as an aetiological factor or treatment for AND and PND,46,47 with the current evidence suggesting that PND should not be seen as a ‘simple endocrine excess or deficiency state’.45

Maternal anxiety, stress and depression have been shown to increase the risk of poorer pregnancy, postpartum, early parenting and offspring outcomes, with untreated maternal depression being shown to be associated with higher rates of pregnancy complications such as pre-eclampsia, prematurity, impaired foeto-placental functioning, and low foetal growth.48–52 Untreated AND and PND have also been associated with poorer outcomes for children including lowered IQ in adolescence,53 impaired language development54 and developmental delay.55

sec.title: Puerperal psychosis
sec.p: Puerperal psychosis (PP) occurs in 0.1–0.2% of women56 in the first four weeks following childbirth with two-thirds becoming symptomatic within the first two weeks.57 Of women who develop early PP, 72–88% have BPAD or schizoaffective disorder and the remaining 12% have schizophrenia.58 Risk factors include a history or family history of PP or BPAD.55 Typically, the mother rapidly develops psychotic symptoms with disorganised behaviour and cognitive impairment;59 28–35% of women describe delusions about their infant56 and 9% have infanticidal thoughts. One out of 500 women with PP will commit suicide.5 A recent study found that for subsequent pregnancies prophylactic treatment after delivery may be sufficient to reduce the risk of relapse.60

sec.title: Specific disorders of infancy
sec.p: The Diagnostic Classification Zero to Three (DC 0–3)61 contains a range of specific disorders of infancy. DSM IV describes ‘reactive attachment disorder of infancy and early childhood’, a disorder marked by disturbed early relationships occurring in the context of ‘pathogenic care’ of the infant.62

In a survey of 18 month olds as part of the Copenhagen Child Cohort 2000, 18.5% were found to have an Axis 1 diagnosis using the DC 0–3 and 8.5% a relationship disturbance.63 The most common diagnoses were regulatory disorder, multi-system developmental disorders and disorders of affect. There was a significant association between regulatory disorders and relationship disturbance.

Within the community, infants may also be characterised as ‘unsettled’, also often called colic or excessive crying syndrome. Less than 5% of infants with colic have organic pathology.64 There is a peak in fussing at six weeks of age65 and it has been postulated that this may be part of normal development. Parents with unsettled babies struggle to access appropriate advice with a trend to diagnose gastro-oesophageal reflux, allergies or lactose intolerance.66 There is evidence that having an unsettled baby can increase the risk of developing PND.67

sec.title: Perinatal mental health assessment
sec.p: Perinatal mental health requires assessment of the mother, the infant and the mother–infant relationship. Research indicates that infant mental health affects maternal wellbeing65 and maternal mental health can impact on infant wellbeing.68 Given that pregnancy and infancy are developmentally important for both mother and child, the importance of a developmental framework for assessment cannot be overemphasised. Any assessment and management plan ideally places findings and recommendations within a framework that identifies risks to child development and works to strengthen family function and support. This should be understood in the framework of prevention and early intervention as well as management of adult mental illness.

sec.title: Specialist management of maternal mental illness
sec.p: Management of mental illness across pregnancy, the intrapartum and the postpartum requires specialised skills and expertise. The treatments commonly used in adult mental health are neither always appropriate nor effective and may present additional risks due to the consideration of foetal exposure during pregnancy.

sec.title: Pharmacological treatments
sec.p: All psychotropic medications used to treat mental illness have limited evidence in pregnancy and breastfeeding and may be associated with potential risks to the foetus and infant. The risk of treatment should always be weighed against risks of not treating mental illness in pregnancy and the postpartum period. Psychotropic medications can also interact with normal pregnancy-associated physiological changes, altering prescribing and monitoring needs. A summary of the evidence for pharmacological treatment in pregnancy is contained in a recent review.69

sec.title: Depression
sec.p: There has been some evidence to support the effectiveness of a range of psychological interventions for AND and PND that are supported by both the UK NICE guidelines and the Beyond Blue/NHMRC Clinical Practice Guidelines.70,71 However, Cooper and colleagues found72 in a controlled study that whilst there was short term improvement of mood, in long term follow up there was no difference from spontaneous remission in the control group. This study also did not find treating maternal depression altered child outcomes.73

sec.title: Psychotic illness
sec.p: A review of models of parent–infant interventions for women with psychotic illnesses found no specific models that had been developed. However, recommended were models that increase maternal sensitivity to her infant.74

sec.title: Parent–infant psychotherapy
sec.p: There are numerous models of parent–infant psychotherapy informed by a range of theories: psychodynamic, family therapy, cognitive behavioural therapy, attachment theory or developed from a supportive approach. Parent–infant psychotherapy requires specialised training and knowledge; however, a survey of perinatal clinicians in Melbourne found that knowledge and understanding of the models available is relatively poor.75

sec.title: ECT in pregnancy
sec.p: ECT is sometimes prescribed in pregnancy for women with severe or life-threatening depressive illness, where the mother may pose a risk to herself and her unborn infant or where other treatments have failed. Risks associated with ECT include foetal bradycardia, foetal distress, placental abruption, the onset of premature labour, maternal status epilepticus and maternal aspiration if the mother is not intubated.76

sec.title: A model for integration
sec.p: The identified needs for specialised assessment and management of mental health in the perinatal period supports the development of integrated, specialist perinatal mental health services within tertiary obstetric hospitals. Ideally, services should aim to provide continuity of care, integrating community health care providers such as general practitioners, maternal and child health nurses and mental health services with obstetricians, midwives and paediatrics; these are important personnel and factors in determining successful outcomes in this population.

Service delivery should address the different needs of women across the antenatal care models and be able to advocate for the appropriate level of maternity care for specific groups of women with mental illness. Women with pre-existing mental health conditions that are currently being managed in either public or private mental health services should be offered a ‘shared care’ model, where women and their community based mental health clinicians can draw upon the expertise and input of experienced perinatal mental health clinicians whilst maintaining the longer term links for mental health care in the community.

Given the significant risk of complications for women and their infants with a diagnosis of schizophrenia or BPAD, management is recommended within a specialist antenatal clinic, ideally within maternal–foetal medicine or other high risk pregnancy clinic, which would afford these women the same level of expertise and care that women with diagnoses which carry similar pregnancy related risks, such as epilepsy, traditionally have received.

There is a paucity of research and clinical care models for women with mental illnesses such as BPD or EDs, yet these too carry risks in pregnancy and the postpartum. It is therefore necessary to develop guidelines for other significant mental illnesses such as BPD and EDs.

Where possible, psychiatry, psychology, psychiatric nursing and other mental health staff should be integrated within specific antenatal care clinics. This is especially important for women at higher risk of co-morbid mental illness, such as women with substance abuse, indigenous women and teenagers. Given the increased risk for poorer developmental and mental health outcomes for premature and sick neonates, services that support paediatrics as both direct and secondary consultation for sick and premature infants and their families should be a part of a perinatal mental health service.

Given the increasing concerns about unsettled infants, integration of mental health within services that manage concerns with infant care, such as early parenting centres, maternal child health nurses and GPs, is important. This assists in detecting confounding maternal depression and infant mental health conditions, including disturbance in the developing parent–child relationship.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Perinatal mental health forms a unique sub-specialty requiring integration of aspects of obstetrics, paediatrics and psychiatry. The perinatal period presents a period of high risk for mother and infant, and disorders presenting during this phase require specific assessment and management. To further develop the expertise and models of service delivery required, there needs to be recognition of this within both psychiatry and clinical psychology. Models of service delivery can then be further developed, evaluated and tailored to appropriately and adequately meet the needs of women and infants.
